     <gmd:name>                         <gco:CharacterString/>                      </gmd:name>                      <gmd:issueIdentification>                         <gco:CharacterString>series</gco:CharacterString>                      </gmd:issueIdentification>                   </gmd:CI_Series>                </gmd:series>             </gmd:CI_Citation>          </gmd:citation>          <gmd:abstract>             <gco:CharacterString>An aerial photograph is a photograph of the earth's surface taken with a camera mounted in an airplane. The geopgraphic extent of this georectified 1.5-meter pixel resolution color infrared (CIR) digital aerial photograph mosaic is approximately the Treasure Valley in Idaho. 48 tiles acquired as part of the 2000 Treasure Valley Air Photo Project are included in this mosaic. The collection area includes almost all of Canyon county, portions of the north-western half of Ada county, the southern tip of Payette county, and a small portion of the south-western tip of Gem county. The 1:24,000-scale color infrared aerial photography used in the production of this mosaiced image was flown in July 2000 by Valley Air Photos, Caldwell, Idaho.</gco:CharacterString>          </gmd:abstract>          <gmd:purpose>             <gco:CharacterString>The images in this collection were used by the Idaho Department of Water Resources to develop land use and land cover data. They are for use at 1:24,000 and smaller scales. No responsibility is assumed by the Idaho Department of Water Resources or the Idaho Geospatial Data Clearinghouse in the use of these data.</gco:CharacterString>          </gmd:purpose> <gmd:DQ_AbsoluteExternalPositionalAccuracy>                <gmd:nameOfMeasure>                   <gco:CharacterString>Horizontal Positional Accuracy Report</gco:CharacterString>                </gmd:nameOfMeasure>                <gmd:evaluationMethodDescription>                   <gco:CharacterString>Data were corrected to 1:24000-scale BLM GCBDs and USGS DRGs. Data was rejected when errors exceeded 12 meters.</gco:CharacterString>                </gmd:evaluationMethodDescription>                <gmd:result gco:nilReason="missing"/>             </gmd:DQ_AbsoluteExternalPositionalAccuracy>          </gmd:report>          <gmd:report>             <gmd:DQ_CompletenessCommission>                <gmd:evaluationMethodDescription>                   <gco:CharacterString>No report.</gco:CharacterString>                </gmd:evaluationMethodDescription>                <gmd:result gco:nilReason="unknown"/>             </gmd:DQ_CompletenessCommission>          </gmd:report>          <gmd:report>             <gmd:DQ_CompletenessOmission>                <gmd:evaluationMethodDescription>                   <gco:CharacterString>No report.</gco:CharacterString>                </gmd:evaluationMethodDescription>                <gmd:result gco:nilReason="unknown"/>             </gmd:DQ_CompletenessOmission>          </gmd:report>          <gmd:report>             <gmd:DQ_ConceptualConsistency>                <gmd:measureDescription>                   <gco:CharacterString>No report.</gco:CharacterString>                </gmd:measureDescription>                <gmd:result gco:nilReason="unknown"/>             </gmd:DQ_ConceptualConsistency>          </gmd:report>          <gmd:lineage>             <gmd:LI_Lineage>                <gmd:processStep>                   <gmi:LE_ProcessStep>                      <gmd:description>                         <gco:CharacterString>1. Purchased 1:24,000-scale CIR airphotos from Valley Air Photos. 2. Airphotos were scanned at 400 dpi, geocorrected, and mosaicked by Eagle Mapping, Inc.The GCDBs were used as control for the geocorrection process. The output pixel size was 1.5 meters.</gco:CharacterString>                      </gmd:description>                      <gmd:dateTime gco:nilReason="unknown"/>                   </gmi:LE_ProcessStep>                </gmd:processStep>                <gmd:processStep>                   <gmi:LE_ProcessStep>                      <gmd:description>                         <gco:CharacterString>All images projected from IDTM27 to IDTM83.</gco:CharacterString>                      </gmd:description>                      <gmd:dateTime>                         <gco:DateTime>2003-10-01T00:00:00</gco:DateTime>                      </gmd:dateTime>                   </gmi:LE_ProcessStep>                </gmd:processStep>                <gmd:processStep>                   <gmi:LE_ProcessStep>                      <gmd:description>                         <gco:CharacterString>All source images created by the Idaho Department of Water Resources as a result of the previous Process Step were mosaicked together using an ArcGIS Workstation 9.2 AML. There was no unique value for NODATA cells. But, the value 255 was set to NODATA to eliminate as much NODATA as possible. Cells that truly are 255 are corrected later in the processing. A boundary clip cover, representing the extent of all mosaicked images, was created from a tile index to use as a mask. To create this coverage, interior arcs were deleted and topology was validated until a single polygon remained. NODATA cells within the boundary clip cover needed to be converted back to 255. This needed to be done to insure that all cells inside the boundary had a value. The values were actually converted back to 254 to leave a value for transparency if it was needed in the future. A mask was created from the image mosaic using the ArcGIS tool ISNULL. In the Environment Settings, the Raster Analysis Settings mask was set to the boundary clip cover. The mask was shrunk by one pixel to make sure the boundary was clean and the final image was created. Data were loaded into an SDE database using JPG compression with a quality of 75.</gco:CharacterString>                      </gmd:description>                      <gmd:dateTime>                         <gco:DateTime>2007-01-01T00:00:00</gco:DateTime>                      </gmd:dateTime>                      <gmd:processor>                         <gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty>
